title: Causal Inference and Active Inference
description: Understanding causal relationships and how Active Inference incorporates causality in modeling and decision making.
learning_objectives: Understand causal modeling in Active Inference

content.overview: Causal inference is the process of determining cause-and-effect relationships from data. Active Inference provides a framework for causal modeling where agents learn causal structures and use them for prediction and control.

causal_models.structural_equations: x = f(pa(x), u) where pa(x) are direct causes
causal_models.interventions: do(x) operations to simulate external manipulation
causal_models.counterfactuals: What if questions about alternative scenarios

do_calculus.do_operator: do(X = x) represents intervention on X
do_calculus.rules: Three rules for causal graph manipulation

examples.name: Medical Treatment Effects
examples.description: Infer causal effects of treatments on outcomes
examples.problem: Distinguish treatment effects from confounding factors
examples.solution: Use do-calculus to identify causal effects
examples.active_inference: Treatment selection based on expected outcomes

examples.name: Policy Evaluation
examples.description: Evaluate causal effects of policy interventions
examples.problem: Estimate what would happen if policy were implemented
examples.active_inference: Policy selection using expected free energy

interactive_exercises.description: Analyze causal graphs and identify confounders
Estimate causal effects from observational data

common_misconceptions.clarification: Causal inference requires additional assumptions and methods
